en.value: ocean
The Pacific Ocean is between America and Asia.
river
The River Nile passes through Egypt.
lake
Loch Ness lake is in the north of Scotland.
waterfall
The Niagara Falls are famous waterfalls between the United States and Canada.
island
Mykonos is a Greek island.
desert
The Sahara desert is the largest in the world.
mountain
The Rocky Mountains are in the United States.
forest
Robin Hood lived in Sherwood Forest.
coast
New York is a state located on the Atlantic coast.
cliff
The cliffs of Moher are in the west of Ireland.
bush
A bush is a small plant that grows around trees.
woodland
A woodland is an area with trees that has little shade.
log
The path was blocked by a very large log.
moss
Moss grows in damp shady locations.
tree felling
Tree felling licenses are required in all European countries.
rainforest
The largest rainforest in the world is the Amazon.
foliage
That tree has very beautiful foliage.
fern
Fern is a very common plant in many forest areas.
dew
We only see dew on plants in the mornings.
I want to live on the coast.
Describing some natural features of our planet
A bit of geography
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
If you could live anywhere in the world, where would you live?
I would live in Canada. There are so many nice [k]mountains[/k] there.
That's where that famous [k]waterfall[/k] is as well... What's it called?
Niagara falls! It's so beautiful!
If you like mountains you should check out the [k]hills[/k] and [k]valleys[/k] in Switzerland.
Good idea, there are plenty of nice [k]rivers[/k] and [k]lakes[/k] in that area too.
If it weren't for the distance to the [k]ocean[/k], I'd move there in a shot!
Definitely! Let's go next summer!
Maria
Alexander
Select the correct option.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
What is the geography of your country like? Are there any rivers? Are there any mountains?

I live in the north of the country, where there are lots of mountains and forests. I live in a valley between two mountains, so we are right next to a lake. I love it, but sometimes I think I would prefer to live on the coast.
The forest
I can't get enough of [k]woodland[/k] walks!
It's so sunny, everything is so bright!
I think it's on account of the [k]dew[/k].
It's beautiful... Oh, careful not to trip up on that [k]log[/k]!
Forget the log, it's the [k]moss[/k] I'm slipping on! I should've worn trainers!
You'd be better off with boots!... When are we going to see some wildlife?!
I know, I wish we were in a tropical [k]rainforest[/k] instead of here!
With all the [k]tree felling[/k] going on, they said that much of the rainforest will be eradicated within the next few decades.
William
Sarah
Grammar: Relative clauses I
The sentence gives us information about the noun in bold.
The man who painted your house was very professional.
True or false?
We played incredibly well in the first half of the match.
The company which I used to work for has just been sold.
We can use relative clauses to give information about people, things and events. We introduce relative clauses with the relative pronouns who, which, that and whose.
The man who painted your house was very professional. The company which I used to work for has just been sold.
The sentence includes a relative clause.
I live in the house with a blue door.
I met a lady whose son is a football player.
I like the cakes that have cream on them.
We can give information about a noun with adjectives and adjectival phrases without using a relative clause:
I like blue cars. I like cars with lots of space.
Relative clauses include a verb and give information about the noun:
I like cars that are blue. I like cars which have lots of space.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I like people
[k]who[/k]
are funny.
[k]which[/k]
[k]what[/k]
I have a friend
[k]that[/k]
lives near you.
[k]whose[/k]
I have a pen
[k]that[/k]
you can borrow.
[k]who[/k]
It's a company
[k]which[/k]
produces mobile phones.
[k]where[/k]
The artist
[k]whose[/k]
painting I bought.
[k]that[/k]
We can use 'who' or 'that' for people:
The lady who / that owns the business.
We use 'that' or 'which' for things:
The car that / which I bought.
We use 'whose' for possessives:
This is the man whose art I was telling you about. (i.e. The man's art)
[k]The person[/k] [k]who[/k] [k]I[/k] [k]live with.[/k]
[k]The lady[/k] [k]I[/k] [k]live with.[/k]
[k]I love books[/k] [k]that[/k] [k]make[/k] [k]me think.[/k]
Sometimes the relative pronoun can be omitted, as in sentence 2. This happens when the pronoun is not the subject of the relative clause:
The lady (that) I live with. - 'I' is the subject of the relative clause, and 'that' is optional.
When the pronoun is the subject of the relative clause we must use it:
I love books that make me think. - 'that' is needed as it is the subject of the relative clause.
She's the type of person [k]who[/k] works very hard.
which
I have a car [k]which[/k] is 50 years old.
who
I live with people [k]who study[/k] at your university.
study
The man [k]whose[/k] house was broken into.
Lots of [k]people I meet[/k] have tattoos.
people that I
Relative pronoun
You should buy food [k]that|which[/k] is locally grown.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
I like people [k]who|that[/k] know how to enjoy themselves!
I want a mobile phone [k]that|which[/k] has a camera.
The author [k]whose[/k] book won the prize.
My father is the one [k]who|that[/k] does the cleaning.
